concept-wr.title: OAM Network Planning
concept-wr.shortdesc: The OAM (operations, administration, and management) network enables the Web administration interface, the command-line management clients, SNMP interface, and the REST APIs to manage the Titanium Server cluster.

conbody.p: The OAM Network is also used for OpenFlow and OVSDB connectivity to an SDN Controller in Titanium Server SDN Configurations, and for syslog connectivity to a Remote Log Server if Titanium Server remote logging is configured.
On systems where an optional board management network is configured for external access, the OAM network also provides access to the board management modules.
US62821 state that IPv6 is supported.The OAM network supports IPv4 or IPv6 addressing. Consider the following guidelines:

li.p: Deploy proper firewall mechanisms to access this network. Ensuring that access to the Titanium Server management interfaces is not compromised should be of primary concern.

US65292 added para about default firewall and optional rules file:Titanium Server includes a default firewall for the OAM network, using the Netfilter framework. You can optionally configure the system to support additional rules. For more information, see .

If topic is removed from this guide, the xref here needs to change to include a <cite> for the Titanium Server System Administration doc.

li.p: Consider whether the OAM network needs access to the open Internet. Limiting access to an internal network might be advisable, keeping in mind that access to configured DNS and NTP servers may still be needed.
VLAN tagging is supported, enabling this network to share an interface with the internal management or infrastructure networks.
US62821 bullet addedThe IP addresses of the DNS and NTP servers must match the IP address plan (IPv4 or IPv6) of the OAM network.
The OAM floating IP address is the only address that needs to be visible externally. Therefore you must plan for valid definitions of its IPv4 subnet and default gateway.

The physical IPv4 addresses for the controllers don't need to be visible externally, unless you plan to use them during SSH sessions to prevent potential service breaks during the connection. You still need to plan for their IPv4 subnet, but you can limit access to them as required.
US62821 bullet addedOutgoing packets from the active or secondary controller use the controller's IPv4 physical address, not the OAM floating IP address, as the source address.
US62821 bullet and sub-bullet addedFor an IPv6 address plan:

Outgoing packets from the active controller use the OAM floating IP address as the source address. Outgoing packets from the secondary controller use the secondary controller's IPv6 physical IP address.
CGTS-5681 addedFor multi-region deployments, you can define a restricted multicast addressing range on the OAM network during system installation.
